IP2026034_syn_1:
Indication: Suboptimal RUL volume reduction. CT shows persistent aeration posterior segment.
Anesthesia: MAC (Propofol/Dex). LMA #4.
Findings: Posterior valve proximal/leaking. Apical/Anterior good.
Action: Removed posterior valve. Replaced with larger Zephyr valve distally. Adjusted apical valve.
Result: Complete occlusion of RUL.
Plan: CT in 6-8 weeks. PFTs 3 mos.
IP2026034_syn_2:
INDICATION: [REDACTED] revision bronchoscopy due to incomplete lobar atelectasis six weeks following RUL valve placement. Radiographic review suggested a paravalvular leak in the posterior segment.
PROCEDURE: Under monitored anesthesia care, the RUL was interrogated. The posterior valve was noted to be malpositioned proximally, allowing collateral airflow. This valve was extracted. A resized, larger Zephyr valve was deployed more distally to ensure a seal. Additionally, the apical valve was repositioned to optimize occlusion.
IMPRESSION: Successful revision of RUL BLVR. Total lobar occlusion is now visually confirmed.

- 31648: Removal of bronchial valve (Posterior segment valve removed due to malposition).
- 31647: Insertion of bronchial valve (New valve placed in posterior segment; Apical valve adjusted/replaced).
Rationale: Procedure involved both removal of existing hardware and placement of new hardware in the *same* initial target lobe (RUL) to achieve therapeutic effect.
Modifiers: None required for facility setting.

IP2026034:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with adjustment and replacement of endobronchial valves, right upper lobe.
Patient: [REDACTED], 65-year-old male with severe COPD status post RUL BLVR 6 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol and dexmedetomidine; LMA (size 4) airway.
Indication: Suboptimal lobar volume reduction and persistent RUL ventilation on imaging and physiology despite prior valve placement, suggesting malposition or incomplete occlusion of segmental bronchi.
Background: The patient underwent RUL BLVR with three Zephyr valves 6 weeks ago. Follow-up CT at 6 weeks showed only partial RUL volume reduction with persistent aeration of one segment. Spirometry demonstrated modest FEV1 improvement but persistent hyperinflation.
Procedure details: Under MAC with LMA, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced. The three existing valves were visualized in the RUL apical, posterior, and anterior segmental bronchi. The apical and anterior valves appeared well seated; the posterior valve was slightly proximal with visible ventilation around the valve. The posterior valve was removed using valve retrieval forceps (collapsed and withdrawn through the scope). A new, slightly larger Zephyr valve was then deployed more distally in the posterior segmental bronchus to achieve complete occlusion. A small amount of mucus around the apical valve was suctioned, and the apical valve was briefly removed and reinserted in a slightly more distal position to optimize seal. Final inspection showed all RUL segmental orifices fully occluded with valves in stable position.
Complications: Minimal mucosal oozing controlled with cold saline. No hypoxemia or hemodynamic instability.
Disposition: Observed in PACU and discharged to the floor on supplemental oxygen.
Plan: Repeat CT chest in 6–8 weeks to reassess RUL volume reduction and fissure completeness, repeat PFTs at 3 months, and close clinical follow-up in BLVR clinic.
